Obituaries submitted on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays are accepted from 8:30 a.m. to 3:00 p.m. by email only Obit@delcotimes.com

(No proofs will be furnished. Pricing will not be available until the next business day after 10:00am by calling Dianne at 610-915-2226)

Obituaries received after Deadline will not be published in the following edition of the paper.

Sending Procedure:

Email is the preferable method for receiving Obituaries (and the only method on Saturday, Sunday and Holidays), they can be sent to Obit@delcotimes.com (Feel free to call and confirm that we’ve received the email)

Formatting:

Obituaries will continue to visually look the same as they currently do, but you will no longer be restricted in what you can say (ex. As much Family can be listed as you’d like; Wording like “Went to rest with the Lord” is now permissible)

Other:

There is a cost for each obituary. Pricing and payments are only available Monday through Friday, 8:30 am to 4:00 pm. All weekend and holiday submissions will be provided a cost the next business day.

Exceptions:

All New accounts, Out of State Funeral Homes and Private Parties will require prepayment upon approval of the obituary. Weekend and Holiday staff are not authorized to set up a new account or process payments

Deadline for the above is before 4:00 PM Mon – Fri. only (Holiday schedules may vary).

Prepayment required submissions will be handled on the very first business day following the weekend and/or holiday schedule. A complete name, address and best contact phone number are required upon submittal of your obituary request to set up your account. A proof will then be emailed for review but placed on hold until payment is received.

” I’m not a specialist but a general practitioner in the world of the arts,” says actor/singer Theodore Bikel. “My predilection is to glory in versatility.” IIndeed, Bikel is one of those performers whose career has encompassed so much, whose face is so familiar, he almost seems like an old friend.

On stage, he was Captain von Trapp in the original production of “The Sound of Music” and has played Tevye in “Fiddler on the Roof” more than 1,600 times. Moviegoers remember him as the German commander, who almost hanged Humphrey Bogart and Katharine Hepburn at the end of “The African Queen”; as the dogged sheriff, who pursued convicts Sidney Poitier and Tony Curtis in “The Defiant Ones”; as the treacherous Hungarian linguist, who tried to expose Audrey Hepburn as a fraud in the film version of “My Fair Lady.”

Bikel also was one of the founders of the Newport Folk Festival and, at age 76, continues to perform 50 to 60 concerts each year as a folk singer and guitarist. He’ll be bringing his act to this area Sunday night at Temple Beth Hillel-Beth El in Wynnewood. “I usually do a broad spectrum of things from quite a lot of source material,” he says. “I can sing in 21 languages, so I do folk songs in various languages, some Jacques Brel, some Weill, and songs from shows I’ve done like `My Fair Lady,’ `The Sound of Music,’ `Zorba,’ `Fiddler’ ~ quite an eclectic mix.”

“Fiddler” has practically become Bikel’s personal vehicle. Although he wasn’t the original Tevye ~ that was Zero Mostel ~ he has played the role more often than any other actor over the past 33 years. He’ll be returning to it again in the fall for a 35-week tour that will culminate in Broadway revival. “Doing Tevye has been a marathon,” he admits, “except that I do many other things and find my way back to it. Over 33 years, I’ve strived to keep it fresh.” Such professional discipline came early to Bikel. Born in Vienna, he grew up in Palestine, and at age 20, was one of the founders of the Israeli Chamber Theatre, the “Cameri.” After graduating from London’s Royal Academy of Dramatic Arts, he attracted the attention of Laurence Olivier in some small London theater productions. He understudied the roles of Stanley and Mitch in Olivier’s production of “A Streetcar Named Desire,” later taking over the part of Mitch. ____________

“Without the arts we are a barren

nation. Respect for the arts is not

something we get with mother’s

milk in this country. It’s regarded

as a frill instead of an integral part

of civilization.”

Theodore Bikel

“Olivier was the premier actor in world at the time, and here he was directing this play,” Bikel says. “Unlike other directors, he could actually show you exactly the way he wanted you to play a scene, but you knew you couldn’t do it as well as he did. It was a little disconcerting.”

Blanche in that production was Vivien Leigh, Mrs. Olivier at the time. “She was strange,” Bikel recalls, “frail, though it seemed there was something very solid underneath.”

From there, it was on to brilliant careers in several fields, working with the greats and near-greats. Mention a name, and Bikel will dip into his treasure trove of memories:

On John Huston, his director on “The African Queen” and “Moulin Rouge”: “Great fun, a practical joker ~ he would go to any lengths to amuse himself.” On Rodgers and Hammerstein, with whom he worked on “The Sound of Music”: “That show was their swan song. Oscar Hammerstein was very ill, and he and Richard Rodgers wrote `Edelweiss’ for me 11 days before we opened on Broadway. It was the last song Hammerstein ever wrote. I often think it’s appropriate that the last word in that song, the last word the dying man wrote, was `forever.’ ” On Audrey Hepburn, the star of the movie “My Fair Lady”: “I was terrified to do the ballroom scene with her ~ I was worried about stepping on her toes. So I took dancing lessons for two weeks before we started shooting.”

In addition to performing, Bikel has been politically active since he became a U.S. citizen in 1961. He was a delegate to the 1968 Democratic Convention in Chicago and a board member of Amnesty International, and is senior vice president of the American Jewish Congress. He has been a passionate arts advocate, having served as president of Actors Equity, as a member of the National Council on the Arts and other posts. “I wanted to make sure the arts, and especially practitioners, are respected in this country,” he says. “There’s an extraordinary and baffling gulf between superstars and others. … We pay homage (to stars) possibly because we don’t have royalty here. But the arts deserve more than adulation of superstars. Without the arts, we are a barren nation. Respect for the arts is not something we get with mother’s milk in this country. It’s regarded as a frill instead of an integral part of civilization,” he says.

Both of his sons have inherited his passion for the arts. Robert is a budding film producer; the younger son, Daniel, is pursuing a Ph.D. in computer science at the University of Pennsylvania, but he’s also a musician. “His apartment looks like a recording studio,” Bikel says. When Bikel isn’t touring, he and his wife, Rita, divide their time between homes in Connecticut and California. But the upcoming revival of `Fiddler’ will keep him on the road for some time. “Beyond that, who knows?” he says. “I take it one thing at a time.” Theodore Bikel will perform Sunday night at 7:30 at the 10th annual Ruth N. Maltzman Memorial Event at Temple Beth Hillel-Beth El, 1001 Remington Road, Wynnewood. Tickets cost $50. Call 610649-5300
